metadata.title: Enterprise AI/Machine Learning: Lessons Learned | by Eric Broda | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: I recently had the privilege of participating on a panel with several AI/Machine Learning experts. There were many great questions, but most were related to how to most effectively establish an…

all_paragraphs: I recently had the privilege of participating on a panel with several AI/Machine Learning experts. There were many great questions, but most were related to how to most effectively establish an AI/Machine Learning (AI/ML) in a large organization.

This gave me an opportunity to reflect on my own experiences helping large enterprise accelerate their AI/Machine Learning journey, and, more specifically, assess what worked, and perhaps just as importantly, what did not work. I have condensed these into a few simple “lessons learned” that hopefully will be useful to you on your organization’s AI/ML journey.

In my experience, your models will never be perfect. So, don’t try to make them perfect. Now, don’t get me wrong — model accuracy (or whichever metric applies in your case) is important, but the getting the absolute best model probably only counts in Kaggle competitions.

Rather, your focus should be to make your models good enough to meet the business need. The fact of the matter is almost all enterprises consider getting a perfect model a very distant second to getting a “good enough” model into production where it can deliver value. So, my advice is quite simple: figure out what is “good enough” for your organization and focus on getting models into production.

This is a fundamental but largely unrecognized fact: today, the vast majority of time in data science in enterprises is not really spent on data science. Rather, most of the time — upwards of 90% of the time from my experience — is spent doing other things, including: acquiring data, engineering data and feature sets, addressing security concerns, setting up infrastructure (cloud, or data center) or workstations, packaging models for production, and creating DEVOPS scripts to migrate a completed model into product… and this is not a complete list!

The unfortunate thing is that in most immature organizations (which is to say most organizations recognizing the relative “newness” or AI/ML) this additional non-data-science work is experienced literally on every project.

Is this a big deal? Absolutely, it is. Let’s say your group’s budget is $1 million (a nice round number, which makes the math really easy), that means that someone — in many cases your high-priced data scientists — are spending 90%, or $900,000, on tasks not directly related to what you hired them for. That is a lot of money! Not only is this painful to hear, but even more painful to experience!
So, how can you avoid this pain? Well, that leads to my next lesson…
As I highlighted earlier, far too many projects are spending far too much time on tasks not directly related to AI/ML.

First, let’s not confuse the what I mean by an “AI/ML Platform. It is not just the environment and toolkit offered by the cloud vendors. Don’t get me wrong, I love the tools that AWS, Azure, and Google offers — you really can’t do AI/ML effectively without them. However, there are material considerations that the cloud vendor tools do not address. In other words, cloud vendor tools are necessary, but not sufficient.

So, then, what is an “AI/ML Platform”? Simply put, the purpose of an AI/ML Platform is to accelerate getting AI/ML models into production. It the “glue” — the scripts, security policies, operability concerns, and self-provisioning infrastructure — that are implemented on top of the AI/ML environments and tools.
In simple terms, the AI/ML Marketplace is a catalog of all artifacts related to AI/ML models that enables model reproducibility, traceability, explainability, and verifiability:

Simply put, the AI/ML Marketplace is the catalog and repository that facilitates modern AI/ML development, management, and governance by fully addressing reproducibility, traceability, verifiability, and explainability.

In most enterprises, I see computing platforms and data/storage volumes scale well beyond internal data center capabilities. GPU farms are not on the agenda. Tripling and quadrupling storage farms is underway. But the fact of the matter is that even large organizations have proven unable to keep up.

Accenture, a large international consulting firm, says there are few issues: First, “until now, there hasn’t been a proven blueprint for scaling, and organizations can fall into some common traps.” Second, “the unfamiliar landscape of AI also means businesses can be tempted to fall back on their time-honored behaviors, reinventing the wheel and building from scratch.” Lastly, “There are many proven, low-cost AI options to buy off-the-shelf and start using right away.”

So why fight it when there are other more capable, cost effective, scalable, and current options available with the large cloud vendors? My simple advice is this: push aside the critics and get your cloud-native AI/ML program started!

Most organizations, especially those moving AI/ML to the cloud, have a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to structure their organization for success. My vision — that which I have seen work in large enterprises — is to “democratize AI/ML”. By this I mean that any group (assuming they have the skills) should be able to build AI/ML models any time, at any speed, using any tools and libraries they need.

But how do you scale and manage this type of organization construct? Simplistically, the fundamental requirement is that necessary guardrails require for scale and management are implemented in the AI/ML Platform and the AI/ML Marketplace. With this in mind, the following is a practical set of groups within an AI/ML organization:

My objective in this article was to provide a few simple lessons learned that will help you accelerate your enterprise’s AI/ML journey and avoid some of the speed bumps and potholes I have experienced. Hopefully I have achieved this objective.

But one thing I can say for sure is that things are moving fast. Technology and approaches will likely evolve, and in all likelihood, I should probably think about writing a new version of this a year from now. Or maybe, after a year, you will be able to write a few lessons learned from your organizations AI/ML journey!
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
I write at the intersection of Data Mesh, Data-as-a-Product, APIs, Event Management, and the digital ecosystem.
